awd_titl_txt: Understanding intraspecific variation in plant defense across resource gradients
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants defend themselves from hungry animals by putting poisons in their leaves and thorns on their branches. There are many other ways they protect themselves, too. Ecologists have wondered for a long time why different species of plants adopt very different strategies of protection. Why wouldn't there be one best way? Even different individuals of the same species defend themselves differently.  Thus, a major challenge in ecology is to figure out the causes and consequences of differences in plant defense.  One idea is that plants in places where they can't grow fast, can invest more energy in defense.  In contrast, plants in places with lots of water and nutrients can grow and reproduce quickly -- life is good, so they don't need as much defense. Scientists with this project will test that idea. They will look at how different individuals of the same species may change their strategies of defense when grown in stressful areas and areas of plenty. They will test how well the defenses work by measuring how tasty the plants are to insects. Results may reveal new strategies for protection of farm crops from insect pests. The researchers will involve high school and college students in the project, training them how to do science. Also, the public will be engaged through various natural history and conservation programs.

This project involves reciprocally transplanting six co-occurring native grassland plant species from populations replicated within eight high- and eight low-resource environments into common gardens located in each region. Resources (rainfall) will also be manipulated in a common garden located in the low-resource region to evaluate the extent to which responses of plant growth and defense to abiotic factors are plastic. Herbivore abundance and the impacts of herbivores on plant fitness (accessed via insect-reduction experiments) will be quantified within populations containing the focal species across the two resource regions. Collectively, these experiments will evaluate how the resource environment influences: 1) growth and defense (both tolerance and resistance) evolution and plasticity within species; 2) positive growth and defense correlations across populations, and 3) insect herbivore abundance and the impacts of herbivory on plant fitness. Ultimately, the multispecies approach employed will help to reconcile the different growth-defense relationships often observed among vs. within species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plants have evolved many traits to protect themselves from the damaging effects of herbivores. Examples of such traits include diverse chemical toxins, sticky latex and physical features such as thorns and tough leaves. Producing these defenses has been shown to come at a cost of other functions, such as growth and reproduction. These costs have most frequently been demonstrated in comparisons across species, but there is also considerable variation in defenses produced among individuals or populations within a single species. Interestingly, however, trade-offs between growth and defense are less well demonstrated in studies of single species. What drives the substantial within-species variation in plant defense without noticeable costs remains poorly known but is critical for developing a more holistic framework for understanding the ecological and evolutionary consequences of plant defense. The first goal of this project was to examine how the abiotic environment (i.e., climate), which clearly mediates plant growth, affects defense among populations of co-occurring grassland plant species. To address this goal, we collected seeds from populations within two distinct and spatially divergent climatic regions (dry and wet) and grew them under common environmental conditions. Our data support a trend emerging in the literature that under favorable environmental conditions, plants can both grow large and be highly defended. Thus, our results challenge the idea of ubiquitous tradeoffs between growth and defense and demonstrate the importance of environmental variation for shaping plant-herbivore interactions. Our results also highlight the complexity inherent in ecological systems because not every species followed these same patterns. For two of our four plant species, individuals in the dryer region were better defended but smaller compared to plants in the wetter region. The second goal of this project was to determine if the negative effect of herbivory increases from short-growing season dry locations to longer-growing season wet locations. Consistent with this hypothesis, we found more herbivores attacking plants in our more productive (wetter) climate region compared to the dry climate region. Importantly, because the plants within the wet region were larger, and therefore better able to tolerate herbivory, they suffered proportionally less damage, despite greater numbers of herbivores being present, than plants in the dryer region. Overall, these results highlight how variation in herbivore pressure and resource availability shape the evolution of plant defense.

This project also created ample training opportunities for postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduates. Trainees received guidance on best practices for collecting data, designing experiments, analyzing data, and communicating results to scientific and general audiences. We also developed material for a hands-on educational module related to evolutionary ecology for high school interns. The module was implemented in 2019 through the Bitterroot Wildlife Internship program in western Montana. We also worked with the Mequon Nature Preserve in Wisconsin to complete a self-guided walking tour with educational signage focusing on plant defenses. The nature preserve is visited by hundreds of public visitors as well as K-12 school groups per year that will make use of the educational signage.
